full_translation:
**The Supreme Venerable Sovereign of the Numinous Treasure’s Scripture of the Ten Precepts**

**Scripture Title:** *The Supreme Venerable Sovereign of the Numinous Treasure’s Scripture of the Ten Precepts*
**Volume:** One
**Base Text Source:** *Zhengtong Daoist Canon*, Numinous Treasure Section, Precepts and Disciplines Category.
**Collated Edition:** Dunhuang manuscript S.6454.

---

**The Supreme Venerable Sovereign of the Numinous Treasure’s Scripture of the Ten Precepts**

The Heavenly Worthy spoke:
Good men and good women who awaken to the spontaneous intention of the Dao/Way and enter the Dharma-gate, receiving my Ten Precepts and Fourteen Rules of Conduct, shall be deemed pure and faithful disciples of the Great Dao. All who, with valor and might, ascend to the heavens in equal merit, advancing in this endeavor without slackening or retreat, shall transcend the Three Realms and become Perfected Ones of the Highest Clarity.

**First:** Refrain from killing; contemplate the lives of all beings.
**Second:** Do not harbor deluded or perverse thoughts.
**Third:** Do not take wealth that is not rightfully yours.
**Fourth:** Do not deceive; reverse false judgments of good and evil.
**Fifth:** Do not become intoxicated; constantly reflect on pure conduct.
**Sixth:** Maintain harmony among clan and kin, without partiality.
**Seventh:** Upon witnessing another’s good deeds, rejoice and lend support in spirit.
**Eighth:** Upon seeing another in distress, aid them in performing meritorious acts.
**Ninth:** If others act against you, resolve not to retaliate.
**Tenth:** Regarding all that you have not yet attained, do not covet.

**Next, the Fourteen Rules of Conduct:**
When speaking to a ruler, bring benefit to the state.
When speaking to a father, show kindness to the child.
When speaking to a teacher, cherish the multitude.
When speaking to a minister, demonstrate loyalty to the sovereign.
When speaking to an elder brother, foster friendship with the younger.
When speaking to a child, practice filial piety toward parents.
When speaking to a friend, uphold trust in your bond.
When speaking to a husband, maintain harmony in the household.
When speaking to a wife, preserve fidelity to her spouse.
When speaking to a younger sibling, observe reverence in ritual.
When speaking to a peasant, encourage diligence in farming.
When speaking to the virtuous, cultivate aspiration for the Dao/Way.
When speaking to foreigners, let each uphold their own domain.
When speaking to servants, exercise caution in their service.

The Heavenly Worthy declared:
Those who cultivate and uphold these pure precepts align with the heart of Heaven. Ever practicing great compassion, they vow to act for the sake of all, universally delivering the world from suffering. Humbly revering the teachings, they must not falter midway. Better to die upholding goodness than to live in evil. Through unwavering devotion, they may escape the Five Paths, avoid the Three Evil Realms, be received by the hosts of heaven, and revered by the myriad spirits. By maintaining a perpetual fast and observing the precepts, they shall naturally attain deliverance from the world.

And so it is proclaimed in verse:
All who cultivate and study,
Vow to realize the true Dao/Way.
With compassion, contemplate the precepts,
The Dao’s voice severs affliction.

---

**The Supreme Venerable Sovereign of the Numinous Treasure’s Scripture of the Ten Precepts**
*(Dunhuang manuscript S.6465, labeled as "Xiang" edition)*

The Heavenly Worthy spoke:
Good men and good women who awaken to the spontaneous intention of the Dao/Way and enter the Dharma-gate, receiving my Ten Precepts and Fourteen Rules of Conduct, shall be deemed pure and faithful disciples of the Great Dao. All who, with valor and might, ascend to the heavens in equal merit, advancing in this endeavor without slackening, shall transcend the Three Realms and become Perfected Ones of the Highest Clarity.

Then the disciples prostrated themselves before the master.

**First:** Refrain from killing; contemplate the lives of all beings.

**Second:** Refrain from lewdness and violating the wives of others;
**Third:** Refrain from stealing or taking wealth that is not rightfully yours;
**Fourth:** Refrain from deceit; do not reverse right and wrong in your discourse;
**Fifth:** Refrain from intoxication; constantly contemplate pure conduct;
**Sixth:** Foster harmony among clan and kin, without false distinctions of kinship;
**Seventh:** Upon seeing others do good deeds, rejoice in your heart and lend support;
**Eighth:** Upon seeing others in distress, assist them in performing meritorious acts;
**Ninth:** When others harm you, resolve not to seek repayment;
**Tenth:** Toward all who have yet to attain the Dao/Way, harbor no expectations.

Next, the Fourteen Rules of Conduct for the Body:
To a ruler, speak words that bring benevolence to the state;
To a father, speak words that bring kindness to his children;
To a teacher, speak words that bring love to the multitude;
To an elder brother, speak words that bring fraternal respect in conduct;
To a minister, speak words that bring loyalty to his sovereign;
To a child, speak words that bring filial piety to parents;
To a friend, speak words that bring trust in fellowship;
To a husband, speak words that bring harmony to the household;
To a wife, speak words that bring chastity to her husband;
To a disciple, speak words that bring reverence in ritual;
To a farmer, speak words that encourage agriculture;
To śramaṇas and Daoist practitioners, speak words that turn the heart toward the Dao/Way;
To people of foreign lands, speak words that uphold the boundaries of their own domains;
To servants and slaves, speak words that bring careful attention to their duties.

The Heavenly Worthy spoke:
Those who cultivate and uphold these pure precepts ever align with the will of Heaven. Constantly practicing great compassion, they vow to act for the sake of all beings, universally delivering them from this troubled world. Reverently honoring the sacred teachings, they must not grow remiss. Better to die upholding goodness than to live by doing evil. Through unwavering devotion, they may be liberated from the Five Paths and avoid the Three Evil Realms. Guarded by all the heavens and revered by the myriad spirits, those who steadfastly observe these precepts shall naturally attain deliverance across the world.

**The Scripture of the Ten Precepts**
This Dharma is truly profound and wondrous,
Freeing your nine generations from bondage.
Should one refuse to receive it,
They sever themselves from the Dao/Way.
Those unworthy who presume to accept it
Will face reproach in this very life.
Upon death, they fall into the Three Wretched Realms—
Take heed, and do not obstruct your own benefit.

In the tenth year of Tianbao of the Great Tang, the year *xinmao*, on the twenty-sixth day of the first lunar month, *gengxu*, Zhang Xuanshi, a male lay disciple of pure faith from Kaiyuan Abbey in Fengyi Village, Yuguan Township, Dunhuang County, Dunhuang Commandery, aged twenty-seven, being but a flesh-bound mortal of no discernment, having received and embodied form, finds his form tainted by the Six Passions. Once the Six Passions take hold, their movement breeds defilement and filth. At times, in what he sees, he is deluded by what he clings to; worldly affairs and karmic conditions arise in succession, drawing forth transgressions and stains, accumulated over lifetimes without end. Thus he revolves within the Three Realms, adrift and forgetful of return; he flows through the Five Paths, bound in long ignorance without awakening.

Having heard that the Most High and Great Sage expounded the *Ten Precepts* and the *Fourteen Rules for Upholding the Body*, and that by cultivating practice in accordance with this Dharma, one may ascend beyond the Three Realms and attain the highest rank of Supreme Purity, Xuanshi, though dull of nature, earnestly seeks to receive and uphold them. He respectfully approaches Master Ma, a Master of the Three Caverns from Mount Song, to receive the *Ten Precepts* and the *Fourteen Rules for Upholding the Body*, vowing to cultivate, practice, and honor them as the treasure of his being. Should he betray this covenant, he shall not dare to seek pardon from the hells of eternal night.

*(Preceding text missing)*
...may naturally attain deliverance across the world.

**The Scripture of the Ten Precepts**
*(Ten Precepts Covenant Text, P.2347)*

In the third year of Jinglong of the Great Tang, the year *jiyou*, on the eighteenth day of the fifth lunar month, *jiayin*, Tang Zhen, a female lay disciple of pure faith from Chongxu Abbey in Changsha Village, Hongguan Township, Dunhuang County, Shazhou, aged sixteen in her precept years, being but a flesh-bound mortal of no discernment, having received and embodied form, finds her form tainted by the Six Passions. Once the Six Passions take hold, their movement breeds defilement and filth. At times, in what she sees, she is deluded by what she clings to; worldly affairs and karmic conditions arise in succession, drawing forth transgressions and stains, accumulated over lifetimes without end.

Across the Three Realms she drifts and strays, adrift and forgetful of return;
through the Five Paths she flows and turns, long sunk in delusion, unenlightened.
Having heard that the Heavenly Worthy, the Great Sage, expounded the Ten Precepts and the Fourteen Articles for Conducting the Body, she knows that those who cultivate in accordance with the Dao may ascend beyond the Three Realms and attain the highest rank of Supreme Purity.
Though her nature in the precepts remains dull and ignorant, she earnestly seeks to receive and uphold them. Reverently offering the ritual pledge, she humbly approaches Master North Peak at the Pass to receive the Ten Precepts and the Fourteen Articles for Conducting the Body, vowing to cultivate and revere them as the eternal treasure of her person. Should she violate this covenant, she shall forever languish in the hells, and dares not presume forgiveness.

**The Scripture of the Ten Precepts**
*(Ten Precepts Covenant Text, P.2350)*

In the year *jiayin* of the Great Tang, the first lunar month, *gengshen* marking the new moon, on the twenty-second day, *xinsi*, Li Wushang, a male lay disciple of pure faith from Chang’an Village, Longle Township, Dunhuang County, Shazhou, aged twenty-seven in his precept years, presents the ritual pledge in accordance with the Dao.
Today, he approaches Master Zhang, a Master of the Three Caverns and Middle Peak, residing in Wuqiong Village, Xiaogu Township, Dunhuang County, Shazhou, to receive the Ten Precepts and the Fourteen Articles for Conducting the Body.
Wushang, a flesh-bound mortal, having received and embodied form, finds his form tainted by the Six Passions. Once the Six Passions take hold, their movement breeds defilement and filth. At times, in what he sees, he is deluded by what he clings to; worldly affairs and karmic conditions arise in succession, drawing forth transgressions and stains, accumulated over lifetimes without end.
Across the Three Realms he drifts and strays, adrift and forgetful of return; through the Five Paths he flows and turns, long sunk in delusion, unenlightened.
Thus, in accordance with the statutes, he presents the ritual pledge and earnestly seeks to receive, cultivate, and revere the precepts as the eternal treasure of his person. Should he violate this covenant, he shall forever languish in the hells, and dares not presume forgiveness.
*(Text incomplete at beginning.)* May he attain liberation across the world.

**The Scripture of the Ten Precepts**
*(Ten Precepts Covenant Text, P.3770)*

In the second year of Zhide, the year *dingyou*, the fifth lunar month, *wushen* marking the new moon, on the fourteenth day, *xinyou*, Wang Yuzhen, a male lay disciple of good faith from Hongwen Village, Pingkang Township, Dunhuang County, Dunhuang Prefecture, aged sixteen, presents the ritual pledge in accordance with the Dao.
Today, he approaches Master Suo, a Master of the Three Caverns and Middle Peak, residing in Anchang Village, Pingkang Township, Dunhuang County, Dunhuang Prefecture, to receive the Ten Precepts and the Fourteen Articles for Conducting the Body.
Yuzhen, a flesh-bound mortal, having received and embodied form, finds his form tainted by the Six Passions.

Once the Six Passions taint the form, every movement breeds defilement. Whether through what is seen or what clings unseen, worldly affairs and karmic conditions arise in succession, summoning the filth of transgression, which accumulates across lifetimes without end. Thus one drifts through the Three Realms, adrift and forgetful of return; cycles through the Five Paths, sunk in long delusion. Therefore, in accordance with the Mysterious Regulations, she presents the ritual pledge in proper form, seeking to receive, uphold, and venerate the precepts, treasuring them forever as the body’s sacred jewel. Should she violate this covenant, she shall be bound in the eternal darkness of hell, and dares not plead for absolution.

**The Scripture of the Ten Precepts**
*(Ten Precepts Covenant Text, Zhensongtang Collection)*

In the *jiayin* year of the Great Era, the first lunar month, *gengshen* marking the new moon, on the twenty-second day, *xinsi*, Yin Zhiqing, a female lay disciple of pure faith from the Divine Farmer Hamlet, Hongchi Township, Dunhuang County, Shazhou, aged eleven, presents the ritual pledge in accordance with the Dao. Today, she approaches Master Zhang, a Master of the Three Caverns and Middle Peak, residing in Wuqiong Hamlet, Xiaogu Township, Dunhuang County, Shazhou, to receive the Ten Precepts and the Fourteen Articles for Conducting the Body. Zhiqing, a flesh-bound mortal, having received and embodied form, finds her form tainted by the Six Passions. Once the Six Passions taint the form, every movement breeds defilement. Whether through what is seen or what clings unseen, worldly affairs and karmic conditions arise in succession, summoning the filth of transgression, which accumulates across lifetimes without end. Thus one drifts through the Three Realms, adrift and forgetful of return; cycles through the Five Paths, sunk in long delusion. Therefore, in accordance with the Mysterious Regulations, she presents the ritual pledge in proper form, seeking to receive, uphold, and venerate the precepts, treasuring them forever as the body’s sacred jewel. Should she violate this covenant, she shall be bound in the eternal darkness of hell, and dares not plead for absolution.

*(Ten Precepts Covenant Text, P.3417)*

In the second year of Jingyun of the Great Tang, the *xinhai* year, the eighth lunar month, *gengwu* marking the new moon of the third intercalary month, on the twenty-fourth day, *jisi*, Jing Xian, a lay disciple of pure faith from Chuntai Hamlet, Longquan Township, Litang County, Yongzhou, aged twenty-seven, presents the ritual pledge. Xian, a flesh-bound mortal of dull awareness, having received and embodied form, finds his form tainted by the Six Passions. Once the Six Passions taint the form, every movement breeds defilement. Whether through what is seen or what clings unseen, worldly affairs and karmic conditions arise in succession, summoning the filth of transgression, which accumulates across lifetimes without end. Thus one drifts through the Three Realms, adrift and forgetful of return; cycles through the Five Paths, sunk in long delusion. Having heard that the Heavenly Worthy, the Great Sage, expounded the Ten Precepts and the Fourteen Articles for Conducting the Body, and that those who cultivate them in accordance with the Dao may ascend beyond the Three Realms and attain the highest rank of Supreme Clarity, Xian, though benighted, earnestly seeks to receive them. He respectfully presents the ritual pledge in proper form and approaches Master Zhang, a Master of the Three Caverns and Middle Peak, residing in Dongming Abbey, Huaiyin Township, Chang’an County, Yongzhou, to receive the Ten Precepts and the Fourteen Articles for Conducting the Body, vowing to cultivate and venerate them, treasuring them forever as the body’s sacred jewel. Should he violate this covenant, he shall be bound in the eternal darkness of hell, and dares not plead for absolution.

**The Scripture of the Most High Numinous Treasure’s Exclusive Exposition of the Ten Precepts** concludes.

chunks.original_text: 洞玄部谱箓类 洞玄灵宝天尊说十戒经 经名：洞玄灵宝天尊说十戒经。 一卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》洞玄部戒律类。 参校版本：敦煌S.6454号抄本。 洞玄灵宝天尊说十戒经 天尊言：善男子、善女人，能发自然道意，来入法门，受我十戒、十四持身之品，则为大道清信弟子，皆以勇猛飞天齐功，於此时#1进心不懈退者，即超凌三界，为上清真人。 一者不杀，当念众生； 二者不得妄作邪念； 三者不得取非义财； 四者不欺，善恶反论； 五者不醉，常思净行； 六者宗亲和睦，无有非亲； 七者见人善事，心助欢喜； 八者见人有忧，助威作福； 九者彼来加我，志在不报； 十者一切未得，我不有望。 次说十四持身之品： 与人君言则惠於国，与人父言则慈於子，与人师言则爱於众，与人臣言则忠於上，与人兄言则友於弟，与人子言则孝於亲，与人友言则信於交，与人夫言则和於室，与人妇言则贞於夫，与人弟言则恭於礼#2，与野人言则勤於农，与贤人言则志於道，与异国人言则各守其域，与奴婢言则慎於事。 天尊言曰：修奉清戒，每合天心，常行大慈，愿为一切，普度厄世，谦谦尊教，不得中怠，宁守善而死，不为恶而生，於是不退，可得拔度五道，不履三恶，诸天所获，万神所敬，长斋奉戒，自得度世。 而为偈曰： 一切修学人，誓愿成真道。 慈悲念戒文，道声断烦恼。 洞玄灵宝天专说十戒经 十戒经（敦煌S·6465云飨号抄本） 天尊言：善男子，善女子，能发自然道意，来入法门，受我十戒、十四持身之品，则为大道清信弟子，皆与勇猛飞天齐功，於此而进心不解退者，则超陵三界，为上清真人。 次弟子对师而伏。 一者不煞当念众生；

chunks.original_text: 大唐天宝十载，岁次辛卯正月乙酉朔廿六日庚戌，炖煌郡炖煌县玉关乡丰义里开元观男生清信弟子张玄誓，载廿七岁，但为肉人无识，既受纳於形，形染六情。 六情一染，动之弊秽； 或於所见，昧於所着，世务因缘，以次而发，招引罪垢，历世你积。 轮回於三界，漂浪而忘返； 流转於五道，长伦而不悟。 伏闻天尊大圣演说十戒、十四持身之品，依法修行，可以超升三界，位极上清。 玄誓性虽愚昧，愿求奉受，谨诣三洞法师中岳先生马，奉受十戒、十四持身之品，修行供养，永为身宝，□盟负约，长夜地狱，不敢蒙原。 （前缺）自得度世。 十戒经（十戒经盟文P.2347） 大唐景龙三年，岁次己酉五月丁巳朔十八日甲戌，沙州炖煌县洪关乡长沙里冲虚观，女官清信弟子唐真，戒年十六岁，但为肉人无识，既受纳有形，形染六情－。 六情一染，动之弊秽； 或於所见，昧所於着，世务因缘，以次而发，招引罪垢，历世弥积。

**The Scripture of the Ten Precepts**
This Dharma is truly profound and wondrous,
Freeing your nine generations from bondage.
Should one refuse to receive it,
They sever themselves from the Dao/Way.

Will face reproach in this very life.
Upon death, they fall into the Three Wretched Realms—
Take heed, and do not obstruct your own benefit.
